title: Corrected Count Increment (CCI) for Platelet Transfusion
description: Assesses adequacy of response to platelet transfusion by measuring the expected increase in platelets adjusted for patient size and platelet dose

parameters.name: time_after_transfusion
parameters.description: Time after transfusion when post-transfusion count was measured

parameters.name: platelet_unit_content
parameters.description: Total platelet content in transfused units

ranges.interpretation: CCI >7,500 at 1 hour indicates successful platelet transfusion with adequate response
CCI ≤7,500 at 1 hour suggests poor platelet response; consider platelet refractoriness and repeat transfusion
CCI >4,800 at 20 hours indicates successful platelet transfusion with adequate response
CCI ≤4,800 at 20 hours suggests poor platelet response; consider platelet refractoriness and repeat transfusion

references: Davis KB, Slichter SJ, Corash L. Corrected count increment and percent platelet recovery as measures of posttransfusion platelet response: problems and a solution. Transfusion. 1999;39(6):586-92.
Bishop JF, Matthews JP, McGrath K, Yuen K, Wolf MM, Szer J. Factors influencing 20-hour increments after platelet transfusion. Transfusion. 1991;31(5):392-6.

Slichter SJ, Davis K, Enright H, et al. Factors affecting posttransfusion platelet increments, platelet refractoriness, and platelet transfusion intervals in thrombocytopenic patients. Blood. 2005;105(10):4106-14.
formula: CCI = (Post-transfusion count - Pre-transfusion count) × BSA / Platelet dose, where BSA = sqrt((height_cm × weight_kg) / 3600)
notes: CCI >7,500 at 1 hour indicates successful transfusion
CCI >4,800 at 20 hours indicates successful transfusion
Lower CCI values may indicate platelet refractoriness
Platelet refractoriness defined as failure to achieve acceptable platelet increment on ≥2 occasions
Alternative causes of poor response: fever, sepsis, DIC, bleeding, splenomegaly, drug interactions
